thread.title: Rio Tinto cuts iron ore guidance
thread.title_full: Rio Tinto cuts iron ore guidance

author: Peter Ker
title: Rio Tinto cuts iron ore guidance
text:
Rio had previously hoped its iron ore shipments would be "approaching 350 million tonnes" in 2015 Photo: Ian Waldie
Rio Tinto has cut its iron ore export guidance for 2015 after weather and other factors weighed on exports during the first six months of the year.
Rio had previously hoped its iron ore shipments would be "approaching 350 million tonnes" in 2015, but said on Thursday it now expected them to reach 340 million tonnes from its operations in Canada and the Pilbara region.
The reduced guidance came despite both production (79.7 million tonnes) and shipments (81.4 million tonnes) of iron ore in the June quarter beating analysts expectations.
The reduced export forecast for iron ore is ironic given the months of criticism Rio has received from Fortescue chairman Andrew Forrest, who has accused the mining giant of flooding the market with supply and talking down the iron ore price by spruiking its plans to continue expanding to 360 million tonnes by the end of this decade.
Advertisement But it is also clear that weather interruptions were the main reason behind Rio's guidance cut, rather than a significant change in attitude.
Rio said that "uncharacteristically severe weather", including two cyclones, had reduced iron ore shipments by about 7 million tonnes during the June quarter, and work at the pilbara mines was also affected.
"Heavy inland rains reduced truck utilisation, resulting in lost production at the mines and impacting the ability to rail planned tonnes (to port)," the company said in a statement.
Despite the weather impacts, sales of iron ore from the Pilbara during the first six months of 2015 were still eight per cent higher than the same period in 2014, and will need to accelerate further in the second half if Rio is to achieve the new guidance announced on Thursday.
It is also worth noting that Rio exported more iron ore than it mined during the June quarter, suggesting stockpiles were worked down during the period.
Rio's weaker than expected first half may help explain why the iron ore price was surprisingly strong over recent months, having averaged $US58.48 per tonne during the June quarter.
The price famously collapsed to $US44.59 per tonne in early July, but has rallied again in recent weeks and was fetching $US50.55 per tonne on Thursday morning.
Unlike some previous production reports, Rio did not disclose the iron ore price it received during the June quarter, but indicated that 75 per cent of sales were priced according to the spot market, the current month average or the current quarter average.
Compared to 2012, Rio is now selling more of its product at prices that reflect the spot or monthly average prices.
Rio left its guidance for copper, aluminium, coking coal, thermal coal and bauxite unchanged for the full 2015 year, but has warned the market that uranium production will be toward to weaker end of previous guidance, on the back of weak production at Rossing in Namibia and Ranger in the Northern Territory.
The miner's chief executive Sam Walsh described the production numbers as "solid".
"We have maintained our emphasis on efficiency and protecting returns," he said in a statement.
The quarterly results came after Rio's Oyu Tolgoi mine in Mongolia had its best quarter in its short history, with production of copper concentrates rising by more than 64 per cent from the March quarter of this year.
Oyu Tolgoi ranks as Rio's most important growth project, and the company's involvement was boosted in May when it resolved long -tanding differences with the Mongolian government.
Rio has renewed efforts to raise at least $US4 billion ($5.4 billion) in finance for an expansion of the project, and a subsidiary noted on Thursday that financing should be arranged and signed before the end of 2015.
Rio shares last traded at $US53.12, having recovered well in recent days from a temporary slide below $US52 per tonne.
